author: jgm
content:
Transfers would be a very useful thing to have, even if they are just between validators.

From an adoption point of view the current "send Ether to the deposit contract, maybe be able to use it in a few years" approach is going to be a tough sell.  Being able to transfer it (withdrawing it back to the Ethereum 1 chain would be even nicer but I understand the difficulties) makes it feel more like moving your Ether to a new home rather than sending it in to the void

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**cdetrio**
iiuc currently there's no standard for checksummed validator addresses, because the Eth1 deposit contract input format is based on the old phase0-1-2 roadmap (where validator addresses were expected to be only "low-level" addresses that users and tooling would never interact with).  If there's any possible of pivoting to a new roadmap (where transfers of bETH will be enabled before phase2), then I'd argue for reconsidering launching phase0 with no checksumming / standard encoding for validator pubkeys/addresses

author: jgm
content:
Are you drawing a distinction between addresses and public keys here?  Because I'm unaware of any address specification to date.

And transfers already exist in the phase 0 spec (see https://github.com/ethereum/eth2.0-specs/blob/dev/specs/core/0_beacon-chain.md#transfers) they just aren't enabled (`MAX_TRANSFERS` set to `0`)

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**cdetrio**
Is it important whether the input to the deposit contract and transfer function is a raw pubkey versus a truncated hash of the pubkey (i.e. an address)?   I'm not sure.  but either way, I think it's important for the format to be checksum-encoded

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**cdetrio**
we saw what happened by launching eth1 tooling and wallets using an address format without mandatory checksums.   there will always a bunch of tooling that continues to use the raw non-checksummed format (I experienced it the other day sending ether for a coinpayments.net payment - it gave me the raw address format)

author: jgm
content: The input to the deposit contract is a modified hash and the transfer function validator indices.  Checksums should be at the user-interface level

author: jgm
content: There has been some discussion at https://github.com/ethereum/eth2.0-specs/issues/1183 but no resolution

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**cdetrio**
iiuc the deposit contract checks a signature so the total input (hash of pubkey + signature from privkey) is effectively a checksum. but it would be cleaner imo to simply adopt a standard format and use it for all the deposit contract tooling for validators and staking.  versus saying validator addresses are low-level and then having two different address formats (one for deposit contract tooling, and another for bETH transfers)
